comments.author: Japjot Singh

comments.text:
All right, kids. I've read enough derogatory bullshit.

What's up with you people? If you think TDK is so monumentally superior, *why 
even watch a clip like this*?

Why bother going down to the comments to take some wimpy, 
passive-aggressive dig at Nicholson or the film itself?

*"Yeah, Jack was OK. But Heath played a realistic psychopath..."* setting 
aside the complete inaccuracy of those kinds of remarks... What pent-up 
frustrations do you hope to relieve by writing this stuff?

I've grown to like *the Dark Knight* quite a bit, actually. Whenever it 
comes on the tube, I watch. But I still view it in realistic terms rather 
than mythic ones, & Christ - *B'89* creams it any any day of the week.

Allow me to expound, as you folks have made me feel compelled to do.

*B'89:*

Loose, naturalistic performances; a lean, mean script; straight-forward, 
uncluttered storytelling; perfect atmosphere (a deft combination of levity 
& gloom); a superior score; a mysterious, tormented & emotionally remote 
Bruce Wayne; a spontaneous Joker with a dark sense of humor & a propensity 
to *cause* chaos rather than recite speeches on the subject; an engaging & 
compelling character dynamic between the two (*"I made you?! You made me 
first."* As a long-time comic devotee, I don't give the slightest of fucks 
about Joe Chill & never will - the most pointless, unremarkable, *"we need 
a guy with a gun for this scene"* character in comic history); & absolutely 
gorgeous production design. The female lead has an identifiable motivation 
somewhat central to the plot... & she's beautiful (& a decent actress) to 
boot. Yes, she unfortunately winds up a 'damsel in distress' - that was 
inevitable in an early comic-superhero film - but hey, at least she brings 
on an intense, operatic finale.

Conversely, *TDK:*

The acting, for the most part, is stiff & weirdly stagey (apart from 
Freeman & Caine, who were outstanding); 3/4 of the *nearly 3-hour runtime* 
is recitation of repetitious, expository monologues (which seem to emulate 
the mindless pontification of David Goyer's); the thread-bare story is 
convoluted with a new plothole (or convenience) every few minutes; Bale's 
Bruce is a narcissistic, tantrum-prone & completely uninteresting wimp; 
Heath's Joker is a one-dimensional cartoon (a growling, violent one, yes; 
but a caricature nonetheless) who pops up out of nowhere with 10 or 15 of 
those wonderful Nolan Bros. monologues in his pocket; there's no element of 
mystery to him despite his lack of backstory (or for that matter, character 
development); he spends more time *talking* about "causing chaos" than he 
does *actually causing chaos*; the theme music (*"Ooh! I know! Less is 
more! We'll just lace the same few cello-heavy lines with tribal drums & 
people will call it intense!"*) is not only as mindless & repetitious as 
the screenplay, but is surprisingly derivative of Elfman's *'Descent Into 
Mystery'* from *B'89*. The female lead - imbued with a thoroughly 
artificial (& borderline offensive) air of girl-power (first awkwardly 
shoehorned in by Goyer in *Begins*), is not only a pointless, grating, & 
unnecessary character, but by the end of *both* *Begins* & *TDK*, she - for 
all her assertive, brassy dialogue - winds up the same old 'damsel in 
distress' character we hoped we'd get a break from.

As someone with a fair depth of understanding of acting & screenwriting, 
I'm still completely lost as to how *anyone* can praise *The Dark Knight* 
as some sort of masterclass when it comes to either.

I probably shouldn't even mention the *visible cameraman* in the 
interrogation scene, the proliferation of horrid one liners that sound like 
leftovers from an unused Schumacher script, or Oldman's Gordon *shouting in 
a British accent*.

Yes, there should've been more focus on Bruce/Bats (& less on Joker) in 
*B'89*; Harvey Dent should've gotten some actual screentime, & Pat Hingle 
as Gordon was *horribly* miscast (& gave one of the worst performances in 
any Batman film), but it's better than making a "Batman" movie that plays 
like drawn out, thoughtlessly produced episode of *CSI*. So either enjoy 
this clip, or go watch something else.

Bats, cheers, & many more years.﻿
comments.author: Charles Incharge

comments.text:
+Rooster Montgomery ha as long as you credit me, i'd be flattered. 
Although... I really don't even like to write stuff this negative anymore; 
I try to avoid it, & there are quite a few things about *Begins* & *TDK* 
which I *do* enjoy.

But I'm so often pushed. And overall? 

They're starchy, stagey, full of bad acting (which is not to say *all the 
acting is bad*), not very well-written, & dour & self-serious to the point 
of cartoonishness - and as long as people insist on comparing them with 
*B'89*, I won't shy away from pointing that stuff out. 

But apart from that, it's like the slagging of *B'89* is almost mechanized 
now. People just come out with the same few digs like robots, and generally 
they're not even legitimate flaws; it's just stuff that didn't appeal to 
their sensibilities, or things they invent to complain about because they 
have this mysterious resentment for the movie. You could flip that around 
and say it about my digs at Nolan's films, of course - but you'd pretty 
much be inarguably wrong. 

Aside from the fact that only I really slag them when heavily provoked, 
most all that I complained about - monologues every few minutes that drag 
on forever, expository dialogue from otherwise-pointless supporting 
characters who happen to pop up every scene, ham acting, plotholes aplenty 
- never mind the hamfisted socio-politcal stuff (subtext & underlying 
themes tend to lose their subtlety & punch when they're clumsily written 
into every character's monologues) or the rather lazy, *poor-mans 
expressionist* cinematography (*"Batman's a brooding character who comes 
out at night, right? Let's just turn the lights way down for 3/4 of the 
movie & drain 3/4 of the color in post"*) - all this stuff that I mention - 
though my list is rather extensive & bitchy - really isn't even 
nitpicking... it's pretty much filmmaking 101. Considering that the *DK* 
trilogy was the work of an A-list blockbuster directer with a limitless 
budget & endless resources, I don't think it's too out of line to touch on 
the reality of the films' quality when some guy's treating them as if they 
were *Lawrence of Arabia* or something - &, more or less unprovoked, 
knocking *B'89*.

(Sorry for going off the trail there for a minute!)
comments.author: Charles Incharge

comments.author: Rooster Montgomery

comments.text:
1966-1968
Romero: I am the joker
21 years later (1989)
Nicholson: Romero? Romero it's dead my friend, you can call me Nicholson
19 years later (2008)
Ledger: Nicholson? Nicholson is dead my friend, you can call me Ledger
And from present day (2015, 7 years later) to 1 year later (2016) 
Leto: Ledger? Leto is dead my friend, you can call me Leto﻿
comments.author: luis monreal

comments.text:
The second those eyebrows went up at 1:26 I knew they cast the right guy.

I think Jack will always be my favorite live movie Joker. He played the 
character to the point: insane, had lots of laughs, silly moments and was 
all about having a good time, all while being diabolically evil. He even 
added a sense of class to the character to make it unique. Hat's off to 
you, Jack.﻿

Great scene in the original Batman. Grissom set Jack Napier up at the 
warehouse where he was attacked and fell into a batch of chemicals. But he 
survived and has come back for his revenge. Its the first time we get to 
meet the Joker. Grissom knows he is in trouble and I love it after he tries 
to get himself out of it." Jack. Jack is dead my friend. You can call me 
Joker. And as you can see, i'm a lot happier!" Brilliant scene in the 
original Batman!﻿

comments.text:
Damn. Both Jokers offer different things. Heath Ledger offers a performance 
that probably connects with more of the audience. But this Joker has some 
insights as well, he's more comic book like and obviously a lot more 
cartoonish, but here and there there's also these things he does or that he 
doesn't do that almost takes more of an emotional maturity before you even 
realize where he's coming from. Both Jokers are seriously awesome 
characters though and both actors put some deep stuff into them.﻿

comments.author: CancelYourCable

comments.text:
This acting is okay, but Heath brought so much more realism to the 
character. His dark psychopathic depiction allowed the viewer to understand 
why the Joker did what he did- because he was insane. This Joker however, 
has no justification for his actions. it's just a caricature with no real 
dimension. ﻿
comments.author: Sarah Radcliffe

comments.text:
Which is exactly how the real Joker is. He kills for the fun of it, not 
because he's psycotic. His end goal is to either kill or break Batman. If 
Batman kills him, he wins. If he kills Batman, he wins. He's not focused on 
playing a game with Batman, he wants to kill the man. 

Ledger was the exact opposite of who Joker needed to be. Joker's not dark 
and gritty, he's bright and upbeat and fun. There's a reason he made Joker 
venom in the first place, it appeals to his sick sence of humor. Nicholson 
played that role beautifully. Ledger is Zazz who found makeup. He didn't 
know who the character is, neither did Nolan.

This was one of tge few memorable scenes from the movie but overall the 
movie was so bad that I couldnt even get drawn in. The movie focused more 
on the Joker than it did the Batman. There was no back story on Bruce

killed by the joker). I dont mind Burton made Gotham more fantasy than 
realistic however that doesnt excuse the poor pacing this movie had. I hope 
Batman Returns is better.﻿
comments.author: Mike The Mighty

comments.text:
1:23 - His jacket rubbed off some make-up on his neck, from take after 
take. No one ever seems to mention it. It always stuck out to me as a kid. 
Just another thing to wonder about The Joker, I guess. Why did Romero wear 
his mustache under his make-up? Why did Burton not see this huge mark on 
Nicolson's neck? I found out the answer to the Romero questions a couple of 
years ago. He thought it made him too dashing to remove it.﻿

comments.text:
+Frodo Baggins It has been said that Bruce often has nightmares based on 
his memories of his parents' death - in these the perpetrator can be the 
villain he is currently after, as he explains to Dick "So you kill Harvey, 
but it's never enough, so you run out into the night to find another face, 
and then another - and then one day you wake up and realise revenge is your 
whole life". Personally I like the continuity that Jack Napier (aka Joker) 
was the one.

But in the golden age the mugger was Joe Chill. Full name Joseph Chilton.

The movie character Joe Chill was based on this minor character from the 
Golden Age Batman.

comments.text:
I think Hamill, Nicholson, and Ledger are the right versions for their time 
and appearences. Nicholson was able to make a comic book character 
live-action, Ledger introduced many new fans to the Batman franchise, and 
gave a darker approach like something out of a graphic novel, and Hamill 
gives a voice to the animated version that fans will hear when reading the 
comics. They all captured the Joker in his insanity.﻿

comments.author: VaristyFootballFkNy0BitCH

comments.text:
I just want to say, it disturbs me how this masterpiece gets averages of 
around 75% or less on review sites like Rotten Tomatoes or IMDB, while TDK 
gets around 90% on the same sites. Now, before anybody gets super pissed, I 
like Ledger's performance, though nowhere near Nicholson. But anyway, I 
like Ledger's Joker, it is a very good performance by the late actor, and 
he saved the movie from sucking completely but again, the movie sucks 
without other than him. Bale's Bruce Wayne and Batman both sucked (yeah, I 
said it, fire away!), Gotham is so bland and boring, the pacing is all over 
the place, and everything else is just "meh" except Two-Face's face. What 
I'm trying to say is, Ledger does not make the entire movie great when he 
is the only thing really good about it. My point is, even if you can make 
the argument that Ledger's better than Nicholson, one that I completely 
disagree with but anyway, taking both Jokers out of the equation, Batman 
defeats TDK in every way, hands down; Batman himself, side characters, 
story and storytelling, music, and style/atmosphere. I don't know, sorry to 
any Dark Knight fans, I just get like this defending my favourite movie and 
favourite villain (Jack).﻿
comments.author: The Neon Reaver

comments.text:
me2 I prefer the 1989 original Batman, it was in my opinion a great 
movie...Tim Burton is my favorite filmmaker, he focused the movie somehow 
on the Joker, in a dark movie  - Gotham - the crazy psychopathic joker was 
really outstanding and made a great contrast to the also great Batman, they 
both were really authentic...I dont like the new Batman film because its 
not funny anymore...
comments.author: CosmosZeroX

comments.text:
+heb430 This was just my opinion. You're free to have your own. I'm glad 
you like TDK because you have reasons for preferring it. You don't need to

comments.author: The Neon Reaver

comments.text:
I never found the 1989 Batman movie satisfying. So many things wrong in 
that movie but a great effort. Even Burton must have known that he wouldnt 
make everyone happy at that time but made the best of his work. Most people 
dont find movies based on comic books satisfiying but most would agree that 
TDK is the closest to what batman is/was in the comic books. Who knows, if 
someone remakes this and comibines ideas from the 1989 and 2008 versions we 
might have something alot more perfect, for now dipshit TDK hands down 
comes closest to a perfect batman movie
comments.author: heb430

comments.text:
The Dark Knight is a genuinely great film, but Christian Bale as Batman / 
Bruce Wayne was honestly one of the weakest parts of it if not the weakest. 
I think Gary Oldman's performance is probably the very best one in the 
Nolan films. His Commissioner Gordon is perfect. Scratchy voiced ninja 
Batman is 'ehhh'.

comments.author: The Neon Reaver

comments.text:
Burton set out to make an entertaining, ground-breaking super-hero 
movie...  He succeeded; Batman is a timeless classic.  Nolan arrogantly set 
out to make an epic movie tailored for the dumbed down, easily brainwashed 
masses.  He cleverly uses cracker box intellectualism and droning, serious 
themes to convince the viewer how epic everything is.
comments.author: mikesteelheart
